16.9oz bottle poured dark brown with creamy foamy tan colored head. 6.9% abv. sweet malt almost lagerish aroma. flavor is sweet malt and almost a creamy texture within the roasted malt. this beer has its own distinctive flavor a bready sweetness that as it warmed was very nice. has a great mouth feel. there is almost a sweet like dried fruit mix but it could just be the malt base...very nice beer.

extremely dark ruby with a big offwhite bordering on tan head, clear but quite dark, nice nice nice lacing... creamy malty, almost has a lactic quality, underneath theres layers of milk chocolate and dark fruits... wow, excellent flavor, medium to medium full bodied, nice chocolate malty flavor, with a nice dark fruit flavor at the finish, lightly dry finish, not sweet at all, drinks easier than expected for doppelbock... Excellent, fairly complex, very complex for a doppelbock... could be a little livelier...

The beer in the glass is bright red and black with medium-pored head. Smells malty sweet and spicy, slightly roasty. Starts very sweet and malty, with lots of caramel and licorice. The middle part is nutty and roasty, slightly hoppy-bitter, with a massive malt body. Goes into a malty sweet, licorice and caramelly finish!

Bottle. Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and a nice beige head. Aroma has nice toasted malts and toffee character, hints of nutmeg and vanilla, finishes with plums and fire pit. Really pleasant aroma on this. Flavors hit a nice charred character with toffee, raisins, cherry pits, rye, with a soft earthy smoke finish. Med body, soft carbonation. Wow pretty fantastic and a close cousin to andechs dopplebock. This is easily one Im sure to go back to during the upcoming cold winter nights.

[500ml bottle, North Bar, Leeds] Pours extremely black with a thin head, very quickly becomes totally flat. Thick, sweet aromas of honey and toffee, sweet malt. On the palate, just wonderful - sweet burnt caramel, honey, liqourice, toffee. Very viscous - can maybe get a little syrupy after a while - but its nothing less than a pleasure [25102011]

500ml Bottle.  Appearance is dark bown/black color with medium, beige head.  Aroma is dark roasted malts, caramel, and some vanilla.  Taste is sweet caramel, malty, roasted grains, and some dried fruit.  Palate is full-bodied, slick texture, average carbonation, and a sweet, spicy, mild bitter finish.  An world-class Doppelbock.

Bottle (exceptionally fresh). Pours with a clear bronze (mahogany) hued body with a lasting foamy, off-white head. Beautiful. Amazingly complex malty aroma. Pretty complex on just the malt alone: grainy, huge melanoidin, bready, munich malt richness, dark fruit, plums, figs, caramelization, raisins, and a hint of spice (hops?). Nothing else; very clean beer. Flavors are deep, rich melanoidin and lots of kettle caramelization. Flan, molasses, bready, grainy, brown sugar. Leans on the slightly sweet side, but very balanced. Rich, dark fruits, raisins and almonds. Still quite drinkable. Fresh and delicious! Slightly bitter balance if any leaning is found. Creamy mouthfeel, light carbonation. Some warming. Medium to full bodied. Absolutely excellent and very fresh doppelbock!
Very tasty dubbelbock. Thin body with hint of honey, short but enjoyable aftertaste.
Burnt caramel and maple aroma. Dark Auburn color with white head. Sweet malty and creamy caramel flavor with some hazelnut. A great example of Doublebock. Gives Paulaner Salvator a run for its money.
0,5 liter fles. Lekkere bokbier. Het zou een nederlanse kunnen zijn. lekker bittr.
Very rich and creamy. Nutty and malty flavors; no real hop presence, gets washed into the background. Typical German lager aromas, rich darker malts.

330 ml. bottle. Dark brown colour, like if it was oak aged. Nicd dark thick foam that that doest hold much, no lace. Sell is earthy,roasted,  spices, chocolate, dark fruits but also apricot, toffee.  Maybe a bit light body and not much carbonation, taste of licorice, roasted, dark fruits, I think I detect a hint of tobacco. Chocolate and caramel too. Very good.

Pours clear ruby mahogany with a big fluffy tanned head leaving lace. Aroma is sweet, acidy, malty, roasted, fruity and caramel. Very nice. Flavor is acidy, fruity, malty, sweet, bitter, bready and caramel. Finishes sweet malty and longlived bitter.
500ml Bottle. Poured well, medium head; tan colour. Roasty, caramel... good balance indeed.  Very nice indeed.

500ml bottle in a stem glass.  Pours very dark brown with a thick, lingering, beige head.  Aroma of nuts, some roasted malts, some chocolate, and light hops.  Flavor about the same.  Average texture.  A really good doppelbock.
Bottle from Alko. Originally rated on 26.1.2010. Well balanced, full bodied and tasty doppelbock with notes of caramel, malts and toffee.
UPDATED: JUN 29, 2011 Sweet aroma with a flavor of chocolate coffee and caramel pours a dark chocolate with a dark tan head.

Bottled, 50 cl. Pours clear deep red with a tan head. Aroma: Caramel, malt, cereal, rye. Taste: Sweet. Fruity flavours. Minimal bitterness at first but increasing. Palate: Medium body. An association with cola. Slick and slightly sticky. Average carbonation. Dry. Overall: Its a decent beer, but a little boring, Id have wanted a bit more.

Pours a dark brown color with a nice off-white head.  Plenty of chocolate and cola notes come through immediately. Plenty of dark fruits, caramel, and toffee with a slight nuttiness.  Very similar characteristics on the tongue.  Plenty of caramel and toffee sweetness along with some dark fruits and chocolate.  Just a faint nuttiness to it in the background.  Medium in body and carbonation.

500ml bottle. Best before 04.02.2012.

It pours a great color, a dark brownish0red with a huge fluffy tannish off-white head that sticks around and leaves some nice lacing.

The smell on this one is great, you can smell it from a long distance away. When you get up close to it you get a bready, roasty, carmally scent that just beckons you to chug. Fresh doppelbock just smells beautiful.

The flavor is right on. It is perhaps a bit roastier than most but that is what makes it unique. Big dark bready flavors meld with a caramel sweetness and a hint of bitterness. 

It is definitely a solid doppelbock.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Enjoyed this more than the Andechs doppelbock. Pours deep brown with a medium, fluffy beige head and a slight red tinge coming through on the edges. Aroma is quite subtle but complex. Toasted bread, brown sugar, molasses, cocoa. Currants and raisins come through in the taste with toasted bread and sweet brown sugar/caramel. Nice mouthfeel. Good beer

9 May 2011, bottle. black, frothy black head. weird nose. musty compost bin or forest floor after a rain. full body, fizzy and creamy. fizzy chocolate drink and a musty wet attic flavour. interesting or odd, i cant decide.

50cl bottle. Pours a chestnut brown with some bubbles and some head. The nose has undergrowth and blue cheese, then chocolate almost toffee. The taste has more of the blue cheese and chocolate, with some fruit on the end. The palate is big in structure, creamy in texture and the finish is fairly clean.

Bottle from German Deli in Sacramento. Pours dark brown with a rich tan head and a toffee aroma. There is a smooth and nutty molasses and dark malt flavor that is quite well-balanced. Goes well with bratwurst.

Würziger, überaus cremiger Antrunk mit leitender Herbe, die das Malz aber trotzdem gewähren lässt. Das Malz wird im Mittelteil fest und nimmt rasch an Süße ab, dabei wird die Würzigkeit durch die Herbe und seichte Getreidenoten gestärkt. Gleichzeitig setzt sich eine toffeeartige Note fest, die im Abgang an Fahrt gewinnt. Im Abgang, in welchem der Toffeeton stärker wird, fährt das Malz allgemein zurück und lässt die Herbe in den Vordergrund treten. Im Nachgeschmack wird das Malz aber wieder ersichtlicher und sorgt für einen langen würzigen Nachgeschmack. Top!

500 ml bottle bought at Holiday Wine Cellar almost a year ago ($5.59).  Pours a darkish brown hue with dark ruby highlights and a finger and a half of beige head.  Aroma of dark caramel and toffee, light fruit esters (grape), and some spicy hops.  Flavor of dark wheaty bread, caramel, molasses, light chocolate, some grape and other dark fruit, and hints of those spicy hops.  Has a strong flavor on the tongue but the sweetness is restrained.  Medium body with some prickly carbonation.  A solid doppelbock.  (666, 536)

Pours dark red with a nice tan head. The aroma is great with molasses, brown sugar, cocoa, licorice and bread. Very rich. The flavor is molasses, bread crust, cocoa, brown sugar, plum, raisins, and a bit of alcohol in the finish. This is a very nice and complex dopplebock.

Picked this up along with a few other Weltenburgers on a recent beer run in Jersey.

Pours a dark ruby red/chestnut brown color with mahogany edges when held to a light and a two finger frothy, light beige head. Decent retention, slowly fading into a lasting ring that leaves sporadic spots of lacing behind.

Roasted malt aroma with hints of chocolate, hazelnut and toffee as well as some subtle spice and earthy hops. Slightly chalky smelling and the earthy hop presence balanced out the sweeter/roastier notes in the nose.

Medium bodied and fuller than expected with a good balance of bitter roasted malt and sweeter chocolate flavor. Dry and roasted up front with hints of dark chocolate, hazelnut, caramel and toffee. Theres also some faint hop bitterness that compliments the roasted character. Some nice bready yeast underneath adding to the body and a ton of chocolate sweetness make this beer very quaffable. ABV well masked with a slight dry finish. Pretty good!

Picked up at Chevy Chase in DC. Served in a pilsner glass.

Pours a dark chestnut brown with a good light tan head and a bit of lacing as it goes down. The nose brings forward a bit of light caramel, some mild nuttiness, and mild earthy hops. Great malt presence all around. The flavor ramps things up with a bit of extra sugar sweetness and strong, dark caramel. A bit of an earthy presence in the dry finish. Slight bit of dark fruits there as well. Good medium body with lower levels of carbonation. Quite drinkable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-07-2011

Deep mahogany body, khaki head. Aroma of dark malts, soft nutty sweetness. Some metallic notes that occurs in few bocks. Flavour has malt, sweet caramel, rich toffee and nut, buttery. Little coffee and roasted chocolate. Very soft, round and smooth.

Very deep brown, near black pour with a large beige head.  Doughy, sweet, bready nose, like baking pastry.  Rich bread pudding flavor with light roast and nuttiness, toffee, a little spice.  Lots of rich and subtle malt flavors on a moderately heavy, sticky body.  Quite sweet, but stops short of being overpoweringly so.  Im impressed by how tasty this is at $3.50 a bottle.
500 ml bottle. Tan head, dark reddish-brown colour. Malty aroma with lots of sweetness, plum and other dark fruits. Malty taste somehow reminiscent of plum pudding. Sweet finish with faint hoppy hue.

Den beste dobbelbokken jeg har drukket. Ølet er lagret på 3 grader 40 meter i et fjell ved Donaus bredder, nærmere bestemt i klosterbryggeriet Weltenburg. Asam Bock har en kraftig rødbrun farge, et fyldig mykt og sammensatt øl preget av mørk malt. Snev av pære og sitrusliknede frukt, karamell, snev av kaffe og humle. Middels bitter med lang ettersmak med fint søtt preg som setter seg i kropp og sjel. Et øl som preges av ekte råvarer og en ekte gammeldags bryggerprosess.

Ein starker nachtdunkler rotartige Doppelbock, der es in sich hat.
Malzig, vollig aromatisch, süsslig, angenehm schwer, intensiv in Duft, stark im Geschmack. Eine weltbekannte  Spezialität wie sein barocker Namensgeber, der maler und Baumeister Cosmas Damian Asam.
Das Bier kann man länge lagern, es wird nur besser.

Tumman ruskean punertava olut. Vaahto on vaalean ruskeaa. Tuoksussa on karamellia, suklaata, lakritsia, hedelmäisyyttä ja yrttisyyttä. Maku on karamellinen, lakritsinen, makea, hitusen katkera, suklainen ja paahtunut.  Olut jättää suuhun kuivan tuntuman. Runsaahko olut, jota voisi maistella jos toisenkin kerran.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2013 Bottle @ home. Pours a dark brown appearance with a two finger brown head. Dark malty, caramel, chocolate, creamy, nutty aroma. Rich caramel, toffee, toasty malty, vanilla, lightly smoky, creamy, a touch fruity flavor. A lot of brown sugar and caramel in the aftertaste. Nice stuff.
Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a nonexistent head. Aroma is roasted malts and alcohol. Flavor is a bit sweeter but still mostly roasted malts and alcohol. Quite nice.

Appearance:  dark cola brown with deep ruby highlights; short, quickly-dissipating head; no lacing.  Aroma:  syrupy sweet malts, brown sugar, caramel, toasted oat crackers.  Taste:  caramel, toffee, molasses, chocolate milk, brown sugar, ginger snaps.  Finish:  viscous, slightly oily, and smooth, with the sweetness giving way to a little dryness.  Notes:  Great appearance, aroma and flavors.  Palate was a little on the syrupy and flat side--would have liked a little more carbonation to liven it up.
Clear dark brown body, large lasting creamy brown head. Aroma of nuts, caramel and roasted malt. Brown sugar. Taste is heavy sweet and has almost none bitterness.

Bottle, shared with esp0r
Dark brown, almost black, white head.
Malty aroma, taste of sugar and licorice. Not a bad beer by any account, but for me its too much malt and less everything else.
UPDATED: JUL 17, 2012 Aroma is sweetish malts, toffee and bread.  The flavor is toffee, caramel and mildly sweet and very deep malts into the finish.
Bottle. Dark with a white head. Sweet smells, maybe some heavy fruits. Heavy taste of malts, you really get the bock-feeling here. Not much aftertaste. A bottle of this is enoug for 3-4 persons

[Bottle] Very dark brown in color. Just about no head to it. The aroma is of heavy malts, molasses, dust and a touch of alcohol. The taste is of dark bread, raisins, brown sugar, dusty grains and cocoa. Light alcohol and metal in the finish. Decent body and lingering sweet/syrupy finish.

Pours a nice dark brown with small, quickly dissipating head. Theres a combination of fruity sweetness with more bitter, chocolate and coffee aftertastes present. Maybe just a touch too sweet (for my taste, at least), but a pretty good example of the style otherwise.
20th November 2006  Warning! Early amateur rating! Deep rich malts, creamy. Slight worcester sauce undertone. No bitter at all.

Már-már feketébe hajló sötét, vörösesbarna szín, gyorsan eltűnő világosbarna habbal. Illata édeskés, pörkölt malátás, aszalt gyümölcsös, kissé karamellás és pörkölt kávés. Ízéről nekem egy jobbféle, krémes desszert jut eszembe, kávé, keserű csoki, amaretto, kevés karamell és nagyon jóféle kakaópor, ezekhez még betársul egy jó adag aszalt gyümölcs. Igazi ízkavalkád bontakozik ki, és minden kortynál más oldaláról mutatkozik. Lecsengése száraz, de ugyanakkor utóíze likőrös, pörkölt kávés, és szerencsénkre jó hosszan tartó. Különleges főzet, szerintem kötelező darab!

caramel malt/ chocolate biscuit smell pours a dark brown, which you can still barely see through in the light minimal head with some retention on the walls of the glass, first taste is a sweetness i cant quite put my finger on, (this is after all my first bock of any type, but surely not my last) then mid tongue would be a sweetness and finishes dry with a little more coffee and slight chocolate overall would say its a good beer but unfortunately i have no other bocks to compare it to, but i got two more in the fridge so ill wait and see

500 ml, BB date reads 17.March2011, into tulip. Pours opaque yet clear dark brown body with ruby shining at the edges, overlain by creamy, beige head with good retention that clings to the walls. The nose is very rich malty sweetness with melanoidin-toasty qualities, strong fruitiness of plums, prunes and raisins brought by malts rather than yeast-derived esters, some caramel and noticeable alcohol penetrating through the thick malty body. Rich malt flavor with melanoidin-toasty character, caramel, dark fruits and roasty notes that, together with light hoppy bitterness, balance out the malty sweetness. There is is a distinctive spicy touch in both aroma and flavor profile, probably originating from the noble hops used. Medium to full bodied beer with moderate to fine carbonation, somewhat sticky, verging on being syrupy coats the lips with a film of sweet residues. Stickier, fruitier, less chocolaty&roasty and not nearly as dry as the Celebrator.
In short: a very malty, fruity Doppel Bock with sticky texture.

[Bottle] Very dark brown in color. Just about no head to it. The aroma is of heavy malts, molasses, dust and a touch of alcohol. The taste is of dark bread, raisins, brown sugar, dusty grains and cocoa. Light alcohol and metal in the finish. Decent body and lingering sweet/syrupy finish. Pretty tasty overall, but I have had better.
Botle. Poured a ruby color with an off-white fizzy head. Aroma was malts, caramel, molasses. Flavor was dark roasted malts, caramel, sweetness. Flavor was a good, rich beer.
Bottle. Pours a clear dark amber color small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel dark fruity aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish hints of dark fruit.

500ml bottle.  Poured a deep burgundy color with a large off white head.  The smell is of rich caramel malts, some light toasted malt, and a some slight notes of fig and raisin.  Taste is roasty malts with some faint, grassy hops and caramel notes. Toffee and espresso notes follow, with a little bit of cocoa. Bittery finish.  Medium syrupy body with plenty of carbonation.

At a tasting, small stable head, clear brown colour with lots of brick red taints,  aroma of dried fruits, brown sugar, nuts and a touch of hay, flavour of bread and dark chocolate, strong mellow bitterness with a touch of sweetness, extremely smooth with no alcoholic presence. Classic true to the style dopplebock though not to complex.

At a tasting, thanks Tomer, pours an amazing deep red liquid, with a nice tan head, aroma of malt, honey, toffee, caramelized sugar, vanilla and nuts, flavor of roasted malt, caramel, toffee, marmalade and a touch of clove, nice bitterness, almost full bodied, pretty easy to drink. Great Classic Brew
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2010 Bottle 50 cl. Pours very dark brown with a beige head. Roasted malts and sweet caramel in the aroma. Flavour is sweet and malty. Very smooth and enjoyable.
500 ml bottle.  Dark brown, thick beige head with great retention.  Aroma of creme brulee and cocoa.  Taste is sweet butterscotch and caramel candy.  Nice.
UPDATED: NOV 20, 2010 Bottle. Dark color - roasted malt, caramel in the aroma. Raisin, brown sugar, cake flavors. Keep an extra one for your friends.
Bottled 50cl. Deep ruby with a nicely remaining light beige head. The aroma is mainly of caramel, herbs and moss. The taste is dominated by moss. Interesting.

4 oz. @ SIB 2010

Notes
"Tastes like a mild scotch ale. Big malt. Pleasant aftertaste. Dark & syrupy."

Serving: 500 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors. 
Aroma: The nose is earthy with a slight metallic note, raisins, pumpernickel bread, and a little bit of yeast. 
Appearance: Pours with a cola like color and a large, foamy, and very active tan head.  Great head retention. 
Taste: There are lots of chewy malts in with that same metallic note showing up.  There is a good bit of raisin and a dark raisin bread.  The flavors come across as a bit flat. 
Palate: Medium to rich body with average carbonation leading to a slightly tinny, bready finish. 
Overall: Less impressive than I was hoping.  Certainly not the deepest or most flavorful doppelbock Ive ever had.
Complex aroma hard to place, nice though. Dark brown beer with minimal beige head. Roasted, malty taste although quite light. Quite nice.

draught at the Local Taphouse Oktoberfest. delicious, best beer i had at the festival. pours a dark copper/red. stonefruit dominated the aroma, with flavours of stonefruits, spices and a sweet caramel malt topped it off.

This is a really impressive beer.  I mean, its a doppelbock, right?  But its incredibly smooth.  The flavors all blend so very well.  The smoky hoppiness, the malts.  Its just a beer that is in harmony with itself.

A nearly black pour with crimson highlights and a fluffy tan head.  It has a bready,  caramel malt aroma with a touch of hops.  The medium body has a sweet taste with average carbonation and an oily texture.  The finish is dry with some slight alcohol taste.

500 ml bottle. Rated @ 12.4.2009.
Pours a dark brown colour with a thick beige head. Looks delicious. Aroma of caramel malts and honey. Bready flavor of malts, mild hops and sweet fruits. Full bodied, sticky mouthfeel and soft carbonation. A delicious brew.

Crazy malt palate.  Malted milk, corn on the cob, and butter maple.  Little hop presence.  Pours a perfect dark brown, almost light black.  Impressive tick frothy head.  A first rate doppelbock.  So you can run and tell that.  Homeboy.
Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is breaddy malt and fruity notes. Flavour follows the nose.

Bottle. Pours a clear and brown beer with a beige head. The aroma is malt, roasted and chocolate. The flavor is malt, roasted and alcohol. The palate is alcoholwarmth with some sweetness. Overall a really good beer.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2015 Bottle. Moderate malt notes of cereal and toasted, light hops and yeast of herbs and dough, with hints of butterscotch, brown sugar and slightly off milk. Head is large, fizzy light brown with no lacing and is almost fully diminishing. Color is clear dark brown. Flavor starts moderately to hevily sweet and faintly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and bitter. Palate is medium, watery with a lively carbonation and finishes a little sticky. Its a little abrubt on the sweetness right off, but this Dopplebock settles nicely into a good drinking beer and a great example of the style.

Had from bottle.  Pours dark brown with huge frothy tan head.  Too much carbonation right off the bat.  Aroma is heavy bready malts with a hint of some spices and a bit of toffee.  Flavor is full-bodied with bit malts, molasses and roasted toffee.  Mouthfeel is less carbonated than the pour and has good body to it.  Finishes sweet and satisfying.  A solid bock.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2010 Bottle: Dark Brown Pour with a mild white head. Smells of raisin bread and yeast. Flavors of Raisin Bread, Lactose, Fig, Yeast, and hops. This was a brew that I expected so much more from, to the point where I question whether my bottle went bad. Such a dissapointment, regardless. 

Update: Definately Bad Bottle the first time, this brew is excellent -

[500ml bottle from Beers of Europe] Deep ruby-brown with a foamy light brown head.  Candy sugar and malt aroma.  Candy sugar continues as you drink through the head but soon changes into lovely chocolatey malts, mixed with some treacle, cough mixture and liquorice.  A growing German grassy hop bitterness fails to sit well with the sweet rich initial flavours, and you realise why these hops helped a golden pilsener culture take off in Germany & Bohemia - they simply dont work as well with dark malts.  Finishes dry yet a little sticky too - despite the handicap of the local hops, this is still predominantly a sweet late evening sipper, and does a decent job of it.

Bottle at SBWF 2009. Nice thick light brown head. The aroma is malty from half dark malts but not so much caramell. A fine bitterness, higher than other Bock biers that give a nice bitter finnish. Big body, just right for the class and smooth to drink.
bottle, via trade with scrizz,  opaque brown black color with tan foam, nice nutty plum aroma, flavors of roasted nuts, chocolate, leather, prunes, malty roast, nice beer

bottle pours dark brown with a tall light tan head.  Aroma is burnt caramel, candied sugar and cinnamon.  Flavor is rich creamy toasted malt, some chocolate and coffee notes and a mellow spiced finish.  This is one of my favorites in this style for how well it flows from flavor to flavor without being too bold.
Bottle sampled at SIB, pours dark brown. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, caramel and some chocolate notes. Excellent doppelbock.

Poured a dark brown colour with red highlights and a deep tanned head. Lacing is good, and a coat of foam was kept on the brew for all of its drinking pleasure. Aromas were of sweet malts with hints of plums and raisins. Taste was awesome ! Sweet and also bitter, with molasses thrown in. Nice smooth aftertaste of nuts. Roasted barley and caramel. This has got to be my favorite Doppelbock (so far).

Very nice dark color with a nice tan colored head. Hints of caramelized malt. The taste is very well balanced between the sweetness on the front and hoppy on the back.
Bought this at Alpine Village - Torrance, CA

Bottle bought in Regensburg.
Very dark brown, with a good tan colored head. Aroma of strong roasted malt, with caramel and cookies. Tastes a bit sweet, but with good hop balance, caramel and a bit of coffee as well. Pretty good lingering finish of hops and burnt malt. A great beer. Not too sweet, great balance, nice to drink. Even nicer on tap, if I remember correctly.

Bottle. Poured a very dark chestnut colour with a thick brownish head. Roasted aroma of coffee, chocolate and caramel malt with notes of  prunes and molasses. Flavour of dark fruits, caramel and coffee. As it warmed, it got sweeter and alcohol smoothed out. Very satisfying bock.

Bottle. Cola-hued with ruby glints. Thin, determined nicotine collar. Pungent, slightly brackish, seriously malty aroma dragging in rye bread, fruit loaf, fennel seed and cooked mussel meat (?). Silky and dangerous with a hint of warm, but no indication of the ABV flavour-wise; its all mellow chocolate-coated raisin, figginess, wholemeal, fruit loaf, malt loaf, big sturdy lederhosen-slapping malts. Rather good.

Bottle. Pour dark brown with a thick latte coloured head. The aroma has got notes of chocolate and some syrup. Complex taste with notes of milk chocolate, salmiak and tobacco. Dark chocolate and a touch of orange in the aftertaste. Smoother than ever... Double bocks dosent get much better than this!

Nice deep brown coloured body with a thick tan head - nice. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, pit fruits and a touch of metal. Medium-bodied; Assertive malty flavours with some spice, a touch of caramel and some good pitted fruit flavours. Aftertaste shows mostly malt and caramel notes and a minor bit of smoke/spice. Overall, a very nice doppelbock - showing good flavours and a good texture. Definitely worth trying if you can find it! I sampled this 50 cL bottle purchased from German Gourmet in Falls Church, Virginia on 22-May-2010, sampled at home in Washington on 05-June-2010.

Poured a reddish black with a large tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and maple syrup.  Taste is very smooth with a good chocolate aftertaste.  Brown sugar taste upfront.  Sweet fruit taste.  Balance is very good.

500ml bottle thanks to blankboy.
Appearance : Pours black medium foamy head. Minimal lacing.

Aroma : Toffee, raisins, dry red fruits and molasses. Some roasted malt and some hops. Light resinous notes.

Taste : Quite mineral. Raisins, roasted malt. Medium sweetness, medium bitterness. Finish has notes of raisins and toffee. Slightly bitter. Body is rather thin. Carbonation is soft. Finish quite roasty (even burnt).

Overall : Quite drinkable and refreshing. Nice nose. I like the raisins and molasses. Very tasty and surprisingly drinkable for such a dark beer at 7%.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Aroma of treacle toffee & cola. Very dark chestnut brown with big beige head. Complex flavour, slightly spicy, dried fruits and caramel. Lively carbonation but quite smooth. Drinkable but no better than that.

Sweet smell of malt, caramel and chocolate. Dark chocolate color, beautiful head that dissipates in a minute. Silky smooth like a Paulaner and longer lasting in the palate than the celebrator. Great Bock, so glad my friend Scott introduced me to this one. He was in  Europe at the Monastery when he first tried this wonderful brew. If you can find it, definitely pick one up.

Full-bodied with a moderately thick head.  Nose has alcohol with some sweet fruit -- figs, dates, etc.  Taste was not my favorite -- the alcohol and a caramel sweetness were prominent and to me, it had a funk to it that I didnt really enjoy -- maybe its the style.    Palate and appearance-wise I cant complain -- beautiful amber color, relatively heavy, long-lasting finish

400.   Dopplebock o clock and this malty  lager is stacked.    Stocky ,fat ,overweight slices of dark malt ...toffee ,banana and soy sauce dance up my nose:  On the tounge , rich malt is met with some smokiness and boozy chocolate .   Some banana and cola ,which is kinda a custom for the style.
bottle, bought at Kloster Weltenburg. Deep brown colour, mid-sized beige head. Malty nose. Full-bodied, malty, hints of caramel, raisins, coca powder, bitter chocolate and prunes.

Már illatában nehéz és szinte bódítóan édes, majdhogynem ragacsos hatású. Mintha mézes-mustárral sütöttünk volna valamilyen szép szelet felsált. Merthogy a malátának valami enyhe füstös illata is ott terjeng a pohárban.
Gyönyörű sötét szín, finom hab, és visszafogottan dús szénsav. Az íze akár az illata. A várt nádcukros édesség keveredik a egy száraz füstösséggel. (A barna mate-tea aromája nyújt valami hasonlót összhatásában.) Ízében a 6,9% alkohol ellenére csak a teltség dominál nincs karakteres alkoholos érzet, fanyarság. A lecsengése hosszú, némileg előbukkan a komló keserűje a háttérben, és az üres pohárban még jó ideig ott érződik az édes illat. Remek választás! Barnamártásos vadételekhez, tárkonyos gazdag levesek mellé, de akár desszertekhez pl. Creéme Brulée vagy egy nehéz aszalt gyümölcsös piskóta (pl. püspökkenyér) mellé is.

Pours deep amber brown with light beige head that dissipates oily. Big nose of sweet malts: caramel/molasses and dark dried fruits: plum,fig,raisen, some prune. Dry dark chocolate taste with molasses and prunes. Smoky-earthy notes linger on the finish. Very nice doppel with complexity, wish it had more body (alittle oily for me...also would prefer more alcohol!) Great buy, if you find it grab it!

Bottle.  Chocolate brown, thin head.  Inviting aroma of nuts, raisins, figs.  Classic doppel taste- sweet malt, fig, nuts, hint of licorice.  Nice and rich- thick sweet brown bread.  The finish unfortunately is a touch harsh- a burnt bitter ending that detracts from the overall taste.  Still very nice, but ending needs to be smoothed out some.  I need to have doppels more often, theyre rich, satisfying, enjoyable.

Bottled. A red hued brown body( bordering dried blood red) with light persistent tan head. Aroma is plum, raisin, maybe even some prunes but also caramel and somewhat significant hints at hickory, like campfire smoke. Flavor has chocolate and dark caramel, but also licorice and maybe, i say maybe, light coffee, also some more darker fruits. Finish is dry sweet malty. I cant wait to pick up more of that.
dark bred, smoke,red/brown ,white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish, nice smoked beer.

Dark, brown with a reddish note. Clear. Has an off-white head, mostly lastng. Very malty aroma, roasted, toasted notes, faint lactic notes too. Flavor starts moderate sweet and finish light bitter. Creamy texture.

Aroma of dried friuts. Smooth and well-balanced flavour with beautiful roasted malts which reminds me a bit to Bernard Cerné. Light molassess and caramel notes. There some dry freshness of bread also in it. On the palate, the alcohol side working which dominates the syrupy full body. Sugar and spice tickling my tongue. Nice deep red body, with beige head, but unfortunately almost lacing. I drink it at room temperature, and it is so versatile. Dry long aftertaste which leaves alcoholic sentience. At the end the sweetiness takes over the roastyness.

Bottle.

A - Deep amber brown with some orange hues as well. Average sized, creamy and foamy light beige head that disappears fast and leaves little lacing left.

S - Deep malt smell with some dark sugar and molasses. Also a good amount of rum soaked dark fruit (plum, date, fig, and raisin).

T - Rich malt flavors with a good amount of caramel and molasses taste, also a little bit of a bread taste. Then gives a bit of a chocolate and earthy bitterness. Finally it finishes with a lot rum soaked dark fruit and some other fruity flavors as well as a good amount of those sweet flavors. Some alcohol taste throughout.

M - Medium body with moderate carbonation. Pretty smooth and a little creamy.

D - Easy to drink, a good amount of sweetness but it is balanced and not cloying.

Notes: A very nice a solid beer. Nothing particularly knocked me back, but it was an enjoyable drink, and an easy beer to drink.

Pint bottle into a lager glass.  The pour is clear and a pretty red/brown with a big off-white head on top.  The aroma is creamy caramel and grain and the flavor is sweet with burnt sugar, cream, and grain as well.

This is a proper, full-bodied dobbelbock. It pours a dark reddish brown with a quickly fading nougat top. Smells of cereal and nuts. Taste is a moderate bitter blend of caramel malts, coffee and toffee. Delicious bubbly mouthfeel accentuating the flavors. Nice stuff. Such a difference from Klosterbrauerei Weltenburgs bland weissbiers.

Very nice doppelbock. Looks black in the glass but is actually a deep garnet when you hold it to a light. Pillowy foam head of mostly small bubbles that leaves behind thick stripes of lace. Raisin and dried fruit dominate the nose with a dusty sprinkling of floral hops. Medium bodied w/ a bit of alcohol to add some dryness which keeps this from falling in the too sweet trap many big lagers do. Flavor is again mostly sweet, tart fruits but w/ some chocolate and coffee notes to add depth. Carbonation is small prickly bubbles which suit the style just fine and provides balance for the strong malt character. Finishes w/ a mildly sticky sweetness that begs for another sip. It has been a long while since I tried Celebrator but I think this ranks right along w/ it.

Pours dark reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma has bread, caramel, earth and a melange of stewed fruits and berries. Alcohol is obvious. Taste is sweet and fruity - figs and dates prominent. Real malt complexity here. Pretty heavy, but the palate is lightened a little by some finishing bitterness. A little too sweet for me.

Bottle. Pours with large tan head over a clear ruby body. Smells of molasses and golden syrup. A smooth malty taste with a touch of roastyness. Sweet, but with an underlying subtle spicy bitterness revealed in the finish. Oily-full bodied.

(Bottle) Poured dark brown and clear with medium sized, fizzy and light brown head. Aroma contained sweetness, molasses and malts. Palate was full bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, molasses, sweetness, chocolate, roastedness and mild bitterness. Aftertaste was roasty and bitter.

The half liter bottle delivered a dark, reddish brown lager with a large, quickly falling tan head and some short-lived lacing.  The aroma is dominated by toffee, chocolate and dried dark fruit fragrances.  Palate entry is markedly sweet and lingers through the finish, but is fairly well-balanced by a dry hop back end.  The flavor profile follows the nose with the toffee, chocolate and plum raisin accents dominating through the softly-carbonated medium-bodied glassful.  Another fine contribution to Western Civilization from the brothers of the Benedictine Order.

Aroma is plums, raisins, candi sugar, bread, chocolate.  The appearance is a deep hazy brown, tinge of red, light tan head.  The flavor is sweet, fruity, raisins, bread.  Very nice.  The finish is sweet, slight noble hops, just enough to make a clean finish.  The beer has a medium/thick body.  Very nice representation of the style.

Comparative tasting with Andechser Doublebock. 
Appearance: Dark brown with maroony, deep-ruby higlight. Amazing tan head with beautiful lace around the glass. Awesome retention. 
Aroma: Just as expected after the appearance: Mellow dark fuits like plum, raisins, Roasted dark, cereals, maybe a hint of milk chocolate or some spicy marzipan(?). 
Flavor: Very pure roasted grains rules the malt profile. Dark chocolate dryness balanced with sweet, alcoholic dried-dates at the medium. Some inviting hop bite with roasted chocolaty layers at the end. 
Mouthfeel: Medium body with almost creamy soft texture. Nice balance between the syrupy malts and the roasted grains. Dry, lingering roasty finish. 
Overall: A very good example of the style. The darker, richer kinda Doublebock what i really prefer...

Mély vörösesbarna színe van aminek a kitöltésnél egy szép krémes világosbarna hab keletkezik ami elég gyorsan összeesik,de vékonyan befedi sörünket.Illata marcipán likőrös és aszalt szilvás.Íze édeskésen,karamellásan és aszalt fügésen kezdődik,ami átadja magát egy keserédes,gyümölcsös,borsos,fűszeres és komlós összetett íznek.Kellemesen testes,az alkoholtartalom végig érezhető de mégsem tolakodó,enyhén szénsavas.Utóízében jelen van a kis mandulás kesernyésség és finom fűszerezettség,kiszárítja a szájat és hosszan tart.Kiadós vacsorák után vagy csak a hideg téli napokra egy kiadós hólapátolás után.Nagy sör!

Bottle.  Had no idea this one was so well thought off.  Poured a dark auburn/brown with an average sized off white head.  Aroma of fruit, caramel, minerals, sweetness and earth, with a whiff of alcohol.  Aroma was solid, but flavor was really nice.  Roasted malt, dark fruit, licorice, nuts, fruit, caramel, earth with a nice sweet presence.  Full with a long lasting finish.  Clean, generous flavors.  All in all, a very nice one.

(From notes, March 16, 2009).  500 mL bottle.  Chestnut brown with a large, short-lived beige head.  The aroma is great; slightly burnt caramel, roasted walnuts, licorice, and a little fresh bread.  The flavour is much the same, although perhaps a touch sweeter than the aroma suggests.  Some bitter chocolate or black coffee bitterness at the end.  Very smooth and creamy.  Excellent beer.

Pours dark brown with faint tan head; aroma is malty sweet and sugary with fruitness and mild chocolate notes; full-bodied, smoothly carbonated; sweet and roasted malty flavor with notes of rye pudding and chocolate; slight bitterness in the finish.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2010 Bottle 500ml. Great doppelbock. Aromas of caramel, toffee, burnt malt, butter, and also copper. Taste has a sweet start, with a long and bitter finish. Syrupy in the palate, and full-bodied. Dark brown colour, with a frothy head.
Nice, dark pour.  Vaguely nutty, slightly vinous/vegetal aroma.  Flavor is rich and delicious with a velvety mouthfeel.

Pours ruby red with large brown frothy and partly creamy head with nice lacing. Aroma of raisins and dough. Flavor of raisins toffee with a bitter roastiness in finish. Medium to full body. A bit too sweet in my opinion but still a very nice beer.

Bottle.  Cherry/prune and chocolate malt aroma.  Dark reddish-brown color with a moderate head.  Sweet dried cherry/prune initially followed by a bitter. lightly astringent chocolate malt flavor.  Very nice.

Good doppelbock that just needs a small push in the flavor department. The beer is a dark brownish red liquid (when held up to the light) with a creamy beige head. The flavor and aroma are very malty. Its a big sweet, bready beer with some hop spiciness. Its just not complex or big enough to really stand out in the style.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2011 opq-dk-br, thin-tan-head, med-body, med-co2.

aroma:  sweet-nutty-roasted-malt toffee.

flavor:  toffee sweet-roasty-^malt nutty minerality funky-lcrc(like Bajuvator but not as much) §tannin(almost grape skin puckery).
§astringent-chrcl-malt(the defining difference from Bajuvator).

too sweet for a session beer for me, but something i keep going back to.

Clear dark brown body, with some visible carbonation and a nice frothy light-brown head. Very impressive lacing and decent head retention.

Loads of malts in the nose, with bready caramel and dark chocolate notes, and a little smokiness. A touch of floral hops in the background.

The taste starts out with loads of caramel, chocolate, and even coffee notes, then going into some strong pleasant breadiness. Some pleasant smokiness develops with time. Very sweet, but appropriate for a doppelbock. Some hints of cherry and honey, together with some nuttiness. The finish is definitely bready and has some roastiness.

Medium-to-full body to it. Very smooth, with a nice sweetness and very pleasant roastiness/smokiness. Coats your mouth and leaves you particularly happy. A nice warming sensation appears after a while.
The alcohol is pretty well-masked, so it drinks very easily. As the it warms up you will feel it more, but, since the beer is just so delicious, it shouldnt be an issue.
All in all, this might change my perspective on doppelbocks! Great beer!

0.5 l bottle.
Deep, non-transparent, brown/mahogany color.
Head is pale brown and minimal, soft carbonation.
Smell is malty, fruity, sweet.
Taste is sweet, flavors of roasty malt and fruit. Body is full, oily feeling.
Finish is sweet-bitter and dry.
Warming-up Doppel-Bock with a nice aroma.

Nice double bock. Deep brown with a small beige head. Fat malty typical german aroma with notes of bread, nuts and minerals. Flavour is very malty with complex mineral notes and light hops in the end. Quite sweet but it balances out in the end. Very smooth mouthfeel with a decent amount of carbonation.

Bottled 500ml. -from beerangel.de shared with Doggythedog and heavy.
Reddish/brown coloured, medium sized tan head, malty nose with hint of chocolate. Sweet malty, chocolate and caramel with notes of grain and minimal dark fruits. Nutty finish. To be honest expected (much) better beer.
Bottle.  Pours dark, dark, brown, with modest head.  Aroma is faily mild for the style, but flavour makes up for it.  Big roasted malt flavour, with notes nof chocolate and toast.  Enjoyed it!

500 ml bottle. From Germany (beerangel.de).
Dark reddish brown colour with big light tan head.
Roasted malty aroma with caramel, sugar, nuts, raisins, biscuit, oatmeal and hints of hops.  Flavour is slightly more straight forward with roasted malt, burned sugar, alcohol, bitter hops and nuts. Excellent complex brew. I like it!

1/11 A 0.5 l bottle courtesy of Doggythedog and ogivlado, thanks for sharing! It poured reddish brown body with medium sized head. Roasted malt, sugar and biscuit aroma. Fine malty flavor, caramel, biscuit and burnt sugar with some herbal bitterness. Roasted malt occasionally ends to be pleasant. Medium bodied with longer sweetish, even slightly alcoholic finish. Fine beer, but not something extraordinary as a such classic should be. Its easily forgettable, and also seems quite weak for a doppelbock.

Pours a deep brown with a nice head and plenty of lace. The aroma is apply with mild chocolate notes and some grassy and hay notes are a surprise but work well in the mix. The flavor is chocolate, cider, some burnt notes, plenty of bitterness, and some raisin and plum notes. The caramel sweetness is very well under control. The mouthful is bubbly but very full. This is exceptional.
Bottle. Thanks to TheJester. Very sweet brown sugar, heavy malt aromas. Sweet malt flavors with some chocolate bitterness. Mouthfeel is kind of sparkling, very good for the style.

Bottle from the beerangel store, shared with ogivlado and heavy Medium sized off white head, thick and not going anywhere for some time. Dark red body, nice. Grainy, sweet, heavy malty nose, notes of dogfood, not bad, didn’t particularly enchant me though. Grainy taste,  roasty maltiness that’s roasty in a way, so dry it’s bordering dogfood again, which isn’t all that much pleasant in my opinion.  No hop, but that’s ok for the style I guess. Sorry, expected more and better, much better.

Beautiful dark amber color with a small off white head. Smell is of raisins, malt, light chocolate, and burnt sugar. Taste was really good with a big malt flavor and only a light bitter chocolate bite at the end that only last for a moment. Very enjoyable doppelbock.

Dark brown brew with a decent dark tan foam, spotty, sticky lacing. This stuff smells fairly foul - something reminds me of fish. Dark roasted malts, some chocolate, grass? Tons of toasted malts in the flavour with roasted as well, raisin, mid range spices works well, burnt sugar, nuts. Smooth medium full bodied brew, mild carbonation, finishes raisiny, brown sugar and weak spice. Good qualities but I really didnt like this brew.

0.5l from the Kloster gift pack sixer.  Poured into a dimpled mug and let to warm a bit.  Pours very dark and the light brown head disappears quickly.  It has a thick mouthfeel and the alcohol taste is prominent.  There is some sweet malt flavor as it warms.
Clear copper brown color with a tan head. Nice malty sweet bready, earthy molasses aromas. Medium body. Earthy sweet fruity, molasses flavors with hearty pumpernickel bread.  nice
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pours dark brown with a small tan head.  Nice caramel aroma, with a rich caramel and raisin flavor.  Body is full.  This is an excellent dopplebock.

Dark red/brown pour with a nice fizzy cream head that settles over time. Nose is a little muted at first, chocolate & coffee notes most prominent, quite heavy on the dark malt. Once warms the dark fruity esters come into play as does the spice. Palate is rather high in carbonation which lightens it up a touch but still rather full. Finishes with a big whack of spice & a hint of abv. Seems to have much more darker malt than i remember from the style. A good beer no doubt, with plenty of complexity.
Mahogany.brown color, nice beige head. Very tasty, chocolate, wood. Full body, very enjoyable.

Bottle from Beersofeurope.com. Pours a deep, dark brown with a beige head which lasts only fleetingly. Aromas of raisins, dark fruits, plums, caramel. Flavours of roasted malts, molasses, chocolate, wood, pears. Finishes sweet and moderately bitter. Belies its strength, very easy to drink.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 26 Sep 2009) Deep ruby colour with frothy, beige head. Malty, slightly roasted nose with notes of raisins and prunes. Malty, roasted taste with dried fruit, raisins and dark bread. Well balanced and smooth finish with a mild, spicy bitterness. More than medium body, balanced sweetness. Lovely balance with a solid malt character makes this a very enjoyable, slow sipping beer.

Bottle. Clear cola brown beer with beige head. Very rich aroma is malty and a bit caramelly. Flavor is even richer. Sweet maltyness, coffee and some chocolate even. Quite bitter in the end. Full body Id say. This beer is truly enjoyable and very tasty.

Dark mahogany with a thick tan head - impressive appearance.  Aroma of caramel malt and honey.  Some earthy yeast aromas when swirled.  Flavor is dominated by sweet roasted malt and honey.  A little bit of licorice in the aftertaste.  Solid beer, but not crazy about the sweetness.
Bottle.  Pours a dark brune body with an off white thin tan head.  Malty chewy almost extract like sweetness, some dry roasted malt.  Some roast y malt notes and caramel.  Raisin and chocolate notes.
bottle 500 ml from Alko 3,45  EXP 25 02 2010 dark brown transparent Taste sweet dark roasted malts  bready bit sticky but decent bitterness in dryer aftertaste. Better than I expected .

Bottle and served in snifter, next to Kaufbeuren Buronator Doppelbock, Allgäuer Cambonator Doppelbock, and Ayinger Celebrator Doppelbock (the baseline bier):  App: All three had a mahogany hue with the Buroator and Asam bocks displaying a bit more reddish highlights as well as a darker more tannish creamy head and better lacing. Cambonator gets the lowest score of 3, the others 4 each.  Aroma: Buronator, heavy caramel malt, bready and alcohol, some prune and fig along with a touch of peaty like smoke, brilliant. The Cambonator displays a walnut tone long with caramel, brown sugar and grape juice, interesting. The Asam bock has the weakest nose of the three with notes of caramel, wood, tobacco, grains, and a hint of raisin.  Taste: Rich and sweet caramel malt is front and center as expected in all three biers as is a hint of molasses. The differences are found with the undertones: Buronator has a figgy and roasty tone along with a dash of mineral water. It seems despite the heavy malt to be the most balanced of the three. The Cambonator has a very slight acidity (again grape juice) and some ashy notes. The Asam has more of a bakers chocolate tone and is more earthy and tobacco like, the most complex of the three.  Mouthfeel: Buronator, creamy and lively, Cambonator, lively and oily, a bit thinner, Asam lush and heavy, dry mineral finish.  Overall: While all three are well done and similar in the basics, the difference of enjoyment and complexity gives Buronator a slight advantage over Asam Bock with the Allgauer Cambonator my least favorite. This is interesting since the Buronator has the lowest ratebeer score of the three. Now when compared to the standard bearer of the style, and Ayinger Celebrator Doppelbock ( 4.2), I found both the Buronator and Asam close companions but still a second cousin, The Cambonator was not even in the same zip code.  Ahhh, the wonders of the horizontal tasting.

Poured from the bottle into a pint glass to drink.  The beer had a somewhat clear dark amber-brown color with a creamy-foamy light tan head, which had moderate retention and cling.  The beer had rich caramel malt aromas with floral and fruit aromas, some raisin and a bit of earthy hops.  The beer had a sweet fruity taste with a bit of grainy bitterness to complement it.  It was slightly creamy with average to light carbonation and a wet body with a good, clingy mouthfeel.  A high quality beer, very much enjoyed.

07.11.2003, 0,5l Bottle. Ølet er mørkebrunt med gulbrunt skum. Ølet har en rik, fyldig smak med både sødme og bitterhet. Ølet er sterkt, noe som gir en utmerket kraft og fylde i smak og ettersmak. Very nice!!

Draft at Gourmet Haus Staudt in Redwood City, served in a stein.  Very dark brown in color with a fairly large off-white head.  Aroma is caramel, roast, and dark fruits.  Flavor is lots of caramel malt, chocolate, roast, molasses, sweet toffee, raisins and other dark fruits.  Palate medium-full and very smooth.  A surprisingly awesome doppelbock.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2012 A cola-brown beer with a big and intensive beige head. Aroma is syrup-like sweet, some roastiness and slightly sour. Sweet and malty flavour, but not too much, ryebread, some chocolate and drying aftertaste. Very smooth and slippery beer to drink. Good beer, where sweet malts are in the top, maybe even too much for my mouth...

Chestnut brown color with an off-white head.  Aroma of raisins, caramel, and molasses.  Chocolate, dark fruit, molasses, and some bourbon on the taste buds.  Velvety texture.  Lacing clings to the side of the glass.  This is a great beer.
Bottle at German restraunt- This is very true to the style. Excellent dark and creamy appearance. Not a heavy as I had expected. Very tasty and smooth. I highly recomend!

Bottle - Mahogany pour with a creamy tan head. The smell is a sweet malt bomb, with caramel, bread, and light bourbon. Oh man...I could smell this all day. Taste is mostly the same--big, sweet, and malty, with just that touch of bourbon. Theres a little coffee and a bit a heat on the finish, along with some nice bittering hops. Its creamy and smooth, just like Id expect. Beautiful.

500ml bottle thanks to and shared with funkybrewster.  Pours a very dark, almost clear, red with a thick creamy light tan froth with some lacing, settlings into lovely super fine bubbles.  Aroma is super fruity, like a fruit-snack/gummy-bear, rich grainy malts, lots of malt flour, very light chocolate, touch of grass 6.5.  Mmmmm the flavor is wunderbar, endlessly malty, loads of grainy malt flour, some faint bitterness that adds dimension, bitter chocolate and malt flour, like drinking rye bread, fantastic 8.5.  Flavor brings huge nostalgia of when my grandfather used to make me chocolate malts as a kid.  It isnt rich but perfectly sweet.  Long lingering chalky bitterness. No hint of any alcohol, well just enough to warm the flavor.  The body is near perfect for flavor and style, avoids being syrupy or sticky like so many sugar doppelbock messes,  smooth ubiquitous super fine carbonation 4.5.  Love it.

Shared with 17thfloor. Pours a a deep ruby brown with a nice billowing tan head. Aroma is your nice nutty malt and caramel sweetness. Only a little disappointing in its lack of punch. Hints of dark fruits and nicely toasty bread. Flavor starts with a very rich toffee and sweet malts. Gains a very nice fruity edge that gives it a superb balance to the nutty and woody character. Finishes with a very rich and fulfilling character. Just tasted some walnut or almond fresh nut lingering. Really nice all around flavor from start to finish. Medium to full body and a rich carbonation. Almost to the level of Celebrator, lacking in aroma but a damn good flavor. Very tasty beer.

bottle into a glass-FIRST DRINK-Nice nutty flavor, deep brown in color and a nice head. very drinkable. LAST DRINK-Ill admit i am not a huge fan of german beers, but this is a definite exception. A very well made beer, head still present to the end.

Sampled at a recently attended lager seminar and poured to stemware a dark brown with some amber tones showing through when held up to the light. The head was a bubbly tan foam which left some spotty lacing. The aroma was thick toasty malt, with caramel, molasses, and brown sugar notes. The flavor was the aroma notes plus a nice, creamy mouthfeel and full body. Impressive.

Bottle. Pours a very dark ruby colour, almost black, with a big tan head. Spicy, fruity nose with coffee, molasses and raisins present. Taste is fairly similar but not too much sweetness. The coffee stands out reminding me of a few of my favourite porters. A full bodied beer that isnt overpowering but very easy to drink.
Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of molasses, chocolate and toffee.  Taste is a full body caramel, toffee with a light bitterness.  Oh man this is good.

pours a dark brown color with a tan head that had great retention, but no lacing.  Aroma was of nice Molasses notes and mild bread.  Flavor seemed a bit lacking.  A good sweet syrup flavor and not much in the way of bready malt notes. Body a a creamy sensation.   Nice but could have been more.

Really suprised to see such high marks for this beer.  I really didnt think it was all that, and I could think of a dozen or more dopplebocks that I enjoyed more but are lower rated.  

The beer pours out a beautiful mahogany brown color, creamy 2" thick light tan head.  The body looks almost purple if you stare at it long enough.  Aroma is toasted bread, sour malts, molasses a bit of roasted pepper.  Flavor has some light molasses notes, and a mineral water like taste...reminds me of sour/tart malts...hard to describe.  Some burnt toast also peeks its head out.  Honestly, it gets a score a bit higher than it should because it looks beautiful in the glass.  The aroma and flavor just arent all that.
Pours dark brown with light brown head. Powerful malt aroma. Very pleasant taste and velvety mouthfeel. An excellent bock.

Dark ruby brown with a firm and lasting tan head. Intense sweet bready malt aroma, with dried fruits, molasses, cognac. Rich and sweet malt and caramel flavour, with darker notes of licorice and dark molasses. Its sweet, but balanced enough.

Bottled sample. Red-brown in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas of sweet malts, plum, cooked sugar, wet stones, and a whiff of smoke. Strong toffee-like malt flavors in the mouth, along with notes of black licorice, mild chocolate, bread dough, and flint. In spite of all of the malt focus, the sweetness is kept right in check by the mineral-like acidity. Very well balanced for someone like me who prefers their beers on the dryer side. Well done

pleasant aroma with notes of caramel, lemony citrus, and candy-like spice; tasty bittersweet flavor with notes of grape tasting fruit, caramel, and a little of that spice; smooth, definitely; good beer - would consider it a regular bock, however.
Extremely bitter, headless, unremarkable. bread crust and alcohol flavors. Not pleasant. I like my doppelbock sweet, and this was far from it. $4 half liter bottle at Zekes Miami Beach.

Aroma of peanuts and molasses with a strong smell of dog food dominant. Clear brown, with a firm thick tan head. Extra full body. Very sweet flavor of roasted barley and molasses. Grassy bark finish. Weird off flavor of some sort of chemical that comes and goes. I dont understand why this is rated as highly as it is, but then again, Im not crazy about bocks.
A nice caramel malty brew with a semi-sweet palate and a hint of tart and spice in the finish. The colour is deep ruby and quite dark. Enjoyable.

Much too sweet, malty and citrusy for my taste.  As a dark bock it truly fits the mold.  Extra strong and powerful brew with a robust finish.  The caramel aroma is potent. Alcohol is definelty well hidden.  Lots of complex esters working overtime and an excellent winter brew.  Too bad I am drinking it in the 90 degree heat!

500 ml bottle in Germany. Weltenburger has been making beer for nearly 1000 years and it shows. Fine dark brown color, smokey aroma, smooth deep malty flavor that lingers. One of the best bock beers of the world. Goes down too easy and will catch up with you if you have many of them. The % is hidden well in the flavor. I dont give out 4s often but here is one.

500 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a dark slightly reddish brownwith small beige head.  Nice aroma of caramel, chocolate and bread.  Flavour is sweet malty with caramel and chocolate giving way to a modest hoppy bitterness.  Medium to full body.  Quite nice.

0.5 l bottle from Alko. Mahagony color with creamy head. Malty, toffeish and nutty aroma with licorice. Sweetish malty flavor with dark bread, toffee, nuts, licorice. Full bodied. Rich malty and bready bock.

Will this be taken as blasphemy? For some it may..but i would say the last 10 German dopples ive had have been weak and some have been a little metallicy- but this one was super tastey. Dark brownish black but somewhat translucent colour with a big tan head. Biscuity malt notes, caramel, toast and a hint of nutmeg flavour. Taste reminds me of a charleston chew. Aroma is malty and rich and very pleasent.

500 ml. bottle. Pours a thick short lived mocha head, with slight lacing over a clear dark reddish brown (SRM 20) body....nose of roasted and caramel malts with toffee and molasses dominating, some raisin and cherry too....tastes of medium sweet malts with toffee, bit of molasses, dried fruits, including cherry withslight bitterinig towards the finish...mouth feel is thick and creamy, a lovely luscious brew.
I didnt know it was so damn good when I bought it. Rich and strong flavor just as I like it. good body and mouthfeel. great beer.

[1900-20081213] 500mL bottle. Light banana coffee roast and some spices in the aroma. Clear, dark red mahogany body with a medium-lasting creamy light tan head. Sweet raisin malt flavour, particular emphasis on the sweet. Medium-full body. Nice to try finally (after a bit of a muddle, oops), drinkable, but overly sugary.

500ml bottle. BB 30 06 09.
Deep bronze body with ruby highlights. Thick tan head sits atop, leaving a spiderweb of lace in its wake.
Oxidised malt aroma, but not in a bad way. Toffee, mollasses, burnt nuts, cocoa, dried fruit, spice, over-cooked meat...if that makes sense!
Richly textured body, creamy carbonation, bit of dryness toward the finish yet a sweetness still remains.
The beer really opens up especially on the body. Plenty of big rich malt characters of toffee, chocolate and nut, yet nothing remotely roasty. Going further are complex notes of raisin, sultana, prune, smoke, wood, earthy spice, bread, subtle herbs. Finishes dry, with a slightly odd bitterness and lingering note of cocoa.
Yum, I do love a good bock. Such a simple and easy drinking beer on the surface, yet complexities seem to form on their own accord amongst the rich malt and alcohol. Lovely.

Pours ruby-brown clear with light tan head
Sugary aroma, flavours of light chocolate and molasses. Goody rounded body, goes down easy
bottle - (asheft) dark brown beer with a thick white head and a sweet toffe aroma. The flavour is sweet and malty, caramel-like.

500 mL bottle.  Pours a deep reddish-brown with a moderate tan hear.  Rich aroma of sweet malts and dark fruit.  Flavour is mildly sweet and a tad spicy, very nice.  Finish is nice and subtle.  Overall a great beer.
Poured dark red with beige hilly head.  Heavy sweet malt aroma with fruits and nuts.  Rich taste of fruits, malts, and honey, much like the aroma.  Smooth and full bodied, great.

pours dark red with a moderate beige head. taste is burnt dry nuts, cardboard, heavy malt. smell is slightly ppper, spicy, a little vinous.  pretty swell for a good style, but nothing stand out and amazing for the price.

500 mL Bottle. Deep dark amber with a beige rocky head leaving good lacing. The aroma is sweet malt, toffee, treacle, and toasted malt; absolutely inviting and what a dark beer ought to smell like. Full rich sweet flavor of toffee, crystal malt, and brown sugar, although a bit sweet for my liking. This one will do as an aperitif after a fine meal.

500ml bottle from the LCBO
Pours a dark ruby red with a big tan head good lacing
The aroma is sweet heavy malts 
The taste is strong malts and brown sugar nutty coffe
not bad

500ml Bottle shared with French Tickler and Grand Genie.  dark brown reddish almost clear appearance with a taned head.  Aroma: molasses, plums, prunes and caramel.  Flavor: prunes, plums, molasses, orge and blach cherries.  Palate: medium body, oily with a prune dry finish.

Dégusté avec french tickler et Agaguk dans un verre du mondial, acheté à la LCBO. Apparence brune ambré au reflet orangé avec une mince couche de mousse. Arômes de blé, orge, caramel, légèrement fruité. Goût de caramel, orge, blé, canneberge et sirop de cassis et de prune. Une très bonne bière avec beaucoup de bagage en background.

Dégusté avec Agaguk, grandgenie.  Apparence brun cuivré foncé avec une belle mousse beige qui colle tres bien.  Aromes melasses, chocolate, sucre brun, prunes, noix, black olives.  Velouté, corps moyen, finition cremeuse.  Saveurs de prunes, cerises noir, noix, orge.  Tres bonne biere en general, bonne equilibre.

Nearly black with a huge tan head.
Smells like sweet bread, malt, molasses, and chocolate.Taste starts with dark cherry and plum with a little bit of sweetness fade to chocolate ending with a malty bitterness. Very smooth and enjoyable.Full bodied and complex. Easy to drink even at 7.2% ABV.

Bottle at Funky Buddha/Case and Keg tasting.  Nice dark brown/reddish pour wtih a good sized off white head.  Aroma is loaded with sweet malt, nuts, bread, and dark fruit.  Flavor follows the nose as you dive into dried fruits, sweet malt, honey and nuts.  Really nice.

20090208  500ml bottle from State Line.  Deep brown color with crazy, thick, dense, beige head of tight foam. Immediate sheeting lace.  Waiting and waiting for the head to dissipate so that I can taste the stuff, I enjoy deep nutty aromas, roasted hazelnut, milk duds, creme brulee, light coffee, and mild smokiness.  Finally.  Creamy texture is coating and lightly bitter to finish.  Flavors are rich, lush, nutty, malty, and lightly sweet.  More light coffee, then caramel, nutella, and molasses cookie.  Ah, this is a nice beer.

(500ml bottle from Fat Cat Norwich) Dark red colour with an off white head that disappears quickly. Smells of rich plum, sweet fruit and malt. Feels warm and thick in the mouth. Tastes of dark berries and fruits with brown sugar and toast overtones. Caramel too, and a tiny hint of chocolate. Very nice, the first doppelbock Ive had and certainly not the last. Perfect as a winter warmer, the flavours blend beautifully together to create a rich, taste centric malty beer that can only be pleasing.

500ml bottle. The aroma is malty, bready and toasty with dark fruits (figs/dates). The mouthfeel is killer. Malty, bready, toasty flavor with dark fruits and a floral finish. This is a beer for people that appreciate a well done, malt-centric beer.

bottle - Pours deep amber with a thin tan, fading head.  The aroma is rich caramel malt with some dark fruit accents.  The dark fruit notes come through nicely in the sweet flavor. Its medium bodied.  Theres just a touch of bitterness in a mostly malt finish that includes some noticeable but gentle alcohol presence.  As one might expect, there are definite similarities to their Barock Dunkel, which I drank yesterday, but the doppelbock version is of course bigger and more flavorful, especially in how much better the fruit notes come through.  Very tasty.

Pours a dark brown color with a quickly disappearing tan head.  Sweet aroma, lots of caramel and bready.  Again, sweet caramel dominates the body, bready, tasty.  Even with all that sweetness, definitely easy to drink.  Top notch.

Pours like a cola. Transparent reddish brown, with a fizzy head thats thick, but dissipates fairly quickly. Gets much better from there, though. Brown sugar and dark fruits are predominant in the aroma and the flavor. Its a bit sweet, but stays dry - very tasty, and very easy to drink.
Somewhat sweet for a bock, still a very good tasting with the aforementioned sugars and a touch of porter coffee smokiness.

Bottle.
Reddish brown color with light tan head.  Aroma is filled with caramel and sweetness. A bitterness comes over the tongue, followed by the fruity-like sweetness and again the caramel or even molasses and a touch of smokiness.  Ein fantastisches Doppelbockbier.
Late forming beautiful head over a dark body.  Nice malts and caramels with a lasting grip.  Usual coffee flavours.  Very nice.

Bottle. Poured brown with a tall creamy off-white head that had a thin layer lasting and good lace. Aromas of wheat, cereal, toasted malts, and a light fruit background. Awesome fruit and malt mix in the flavor. Medium to full body, creamy smooth, sweet throughout. A very nice Bock.
Nice dark color and easy head. Molasses caramel and heavey bread flavor and arouma. Mild in a way with a sweet finish.

500 mL. Pours a deep ruby with a thin Coco-Cola like head fizzy head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is red licorice, malt, molasses, caramel, milk chocolate. Has a good dark malt backbone along with rye bread, chocolate, licorice, and good balancing hops. Oily mouthfeel. Lots of coating. Long, sweet finish. Best doppelbock aside from Celebrator that I have tried.

50 cL bottle. Pours dark hazzlenut brown with a light brown head. Dense sweet caramel and breadish aroma with a lot fruity accents. Smooth and sweet flavoured yet softly balanced by hops to provide a nice uplifting flavour to the dense and sweet malt. Smooth and lingering finish. Lovely

Deep mahogogany with a huge beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel, rye bread and hints of chocolate. Flavour was sweet with notes of roasted malt, bread,  caramel and toffee. Finished quite sweet.

Bottle. Pours deepest brown/red with a thick creamy head.  Lacing in rings.  Aroma is malt and caramel.  Flavour is malt, caramel, toasted molasses like in biscuits,  Malty sweet finish.  A good beer with Christmas sweets and nuts
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Pours a dark mahogany red with a full creamy tan head. Malt greets the nose. Mouthfeel is very creamy. Tastes of dark roasted malt, chocolate, molasses and a hint of coffee. No bitterness on the finish. Pairs well with roasted nuts, red meat or the picnic food group. Overall, a delightful beer.

1 year aged..11.15.08 best before.... light foam, low lacing, dark brown .. smells of mop water after a caramel clean up in a dirt pool ... light choc covered pennies ... light in the mouth, as well as the chest .. muddled but kinda tasty .. thanks stu, i have a crowbar  ... this aint the ronald mcmoney scene...
Dark brown colour with a beige head. Sweet malty aroma. The flavour is malty, sweet and caramelish. Medium to full-bodied, sweet and slightly bitter finish. Very good doppelbock.

Bottled. Deep intensive ruby, lovely creamy beige head.  Buttery rye bread aroma, malty ans simple. Sweet rye bread malty flavor w/ liquorice, rye pudding, little dried fruits. Herbal and slightly ashy finish. Full bodied, lush mouthfilling carbonation. A good, soothing dobbelbock.
Picked up at Maruhn Getränke in Darmstadt.  Pours a nice dark brown.  Aroma of malt, nuts, hops. Tastes malty, with some hops and roasty hints.

A well balanced tasty dark german brew.  prunes/raisins, caramel, scotch and chocolate all available here.  Not an every day drinker so not a favorite for me...but defenitely something delicious I will come back to.

Pours clear yet dark amber with infra red edges and firm wavy frothy nearly creamy tan head. Great looking brew.  I can get a sense of the aroma from three feet away.  Upon closer inspection I get a pleasing combination of roasted malts, some graininess and sweet caramel candy to go along with a light amount of estery sting. Good gravy, the taste is luscious. I get rich roasty malts mingling first with a moderate level of dark fruity esters and then creamy caramel. Wow. By midway Im detecting a bit of chocolate malts, biscuit malts and mild nuttiness. This is bold yet smooth.  Just delicious.

Excellently crafted beer. Poured from a bottle purchased in Miami Beach with a fine, tan, foamy, frothy, slightly textured head and some lace. Very dark walnut color with dark amber highlights. Aroma is malty, slight anise and rootbeer. Flavor’s the same but first dry and then sweet. Great body! Silky smooth, fine carbonation and mouth filling. Hints of alcohol. Good finish but maybe too much for a session beer.

50cl bottle from Beverage Castle (Tampa, FL). Pours a clear dark brown-reddish color with a thick and foamy tan head that settles quickly but still laces the glass. Aroma is sweet malt, milk chocolate, banana, some hints of honey, caramel and malted milk. Flavor is pretty much the same -- lots of sweet malt, chocolate, maybe some hints of toffee, caramel and ripe fruit. Generally medium body with a sweet and slightly hoppy finish.

A Mes rate: bottle from the Bottle Stop in Bramhall.What an unexpected cracker this is. Almost black brown with a thick and creamy beige head that lasts well. A ton of caramel and rich German malts on the nose with some slight hay and almost barnyardy funk plus a lovely delicate hint of wood smoke. The flavour follows on beautifully with slight dark chocolate notes giving a subtle bitterness that balances things out superbly. Glorious finish full of chewy malt and a slight nod toward the alcohol content leaving a lingering sweet smoky aftertaste. Very good stuff indeed.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2009 Bottle.  Pours a not quite opaque dark brown with ruby showing against light.  Big creamy tan head that laces the glass thickly.  Beautiful beer.  Flavor is rich malts with hints of chocolote.  Dry malt predominates in this brew which becomes slightly estery as it warms.  Full bodied and mouthfilling with a very dry finish.

Pour is dark brown with a light tan fizzy head.  Aroma is malty with sweet butter, brown sugar, and dark fruit.  Flavor is sweet roasted malt, light chocolate, biscuits, and goodness.  Very smooth carbonation. I also got a bit of toffee characters throughout the brew.  Very solid beer.  Would buy again.
500 ml bottle. Deep brown color, creamy tan head. Very appealing sweet aroma with some raisins. Wickedly smooth taste with a chocolaty finish, full body. Great!

Splendida doppelbock di Weltenburger, uno dei prodotti di punta del birrificio; servita nel bicchiere tozzo, si lascia bere con generosità ma interessa soprattutto le papille gustative e il naso (splendido, di prugna e zucchero candito).

Bottle. I’ve had one of those runs of beers where I thought sod trying something new, lets go back to the old favourites, then this little belter came along. Dark brown with a hint of red with a creamy beige head. Dark fruit cake with a roasted kiss. Very nice indeed and will certainly have again.
scura buona schiuma persistente il naso è intenso fruttato leggero caramello miele di castagno in bocca morbida fruttata piena piuttosto intensa non molto amara leggera tostaura

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2008 bottle.  Pours a ruby red with a light brown head.  Nose is nutty and bready with malt prominent.  Taste is bready and roast malt.  Mouthfeel is medium with some bitterness.  A very drinkable brew.  Liked this quite a bit.

Bottled. A dark brown to reddish beer. The head is beige and medium sized, a bit creamy but diminishing. Nice lacing. Rich, malty aroma is bready and medium roasted and  some licorice, raisin and hops. A hint of alcohol in the finish with chocolate tones. Aroma is sweetish bready with sweetness of dried fruits. The finish is medium bitter and more roasted. Medium to full bodied, oily and a bit sticky texture. Soft and smooth carbonation. A very good doppelbock.

Bottle. Heavy malty smell, a little bit like a soy sauce and a little bit of alcohol. A small light brown fizzy head which is fast and fully diminishing. The body is dark red. Light sweet and moderate bitter with a medium duration. The body is medium with an oily texture and a rather flat carbonation.

500 ml bottle: poured dark brown with a medium sized tan head. Rich aroma of caramel malt, dark fruit, a touch of chocolate. Flavor is full with lots of roasted malt, caramel, some hops, and chocolate. A bit of sweetness initially followed up by a moderately dry finish. Good.

I saw this fine brew on the list of a beer festival about five years ago and quickly put it on my "to sample" list.  But when I approached the appropriate table, the worker insisted that it wasn’t one of the beers at that booth.  I never did find it.

So imagine my pleasure when I finally saw this, in bottle, at a local store...after five long years and with a name that still came easily to mind, making it instantly recognizable.  To build up such hopes...well, it can lead to disappointment.  But not this time.

This nice doppelbock pours a dark, burgundy tinged brown, with a large, light tan head.  Nose is a nice interplay of sweetness from rich, dark fruits, roast and chocolate, and malt, of course.  Flavor is much the same, with the roast and dark fruit flavors dominating, but very well rounded overall.  Really, a lovely beer, and one that I’m happy to have found nearby (and at what I think is a pretty good price!).  Well worth the wait!

(bottle) darkest ruby-red colour with a bubbly mahogany head. strong nose of dark fruits, with cookie-dough, chocolate and a few roasted touches. flavour has a fresh roasted malt base that accentuates all the components of the aroma, along with a delicate hop spiciness and a light alcohol touch. medium and well-balanced body, not too sweet.

500 mL bottle from Wine Warehouse, dated 11.01.02. Reddish brown pour with a 2-finger head. Aroma of brown sugar, banana and grain. Taste is wheat, brown sugar, raisins, banana, caramel. Full bodied but very light texture. Very nice.

If you are looking for something very malty this is your beer, it is also very full boided and has great balance along with a nice mouthfeel. The caramelly sweetness in this works very well, the metallic notes play second fiddle and get ignored by me mostly.  A highly recommended beer in my books.

Bottle. Dark brown. Small off white head that didn’t last. Left a little lacing. Smells very malty - cereal/weetbix dominates with some toffee. Tastes very malty as well - toffee, molassas, cereal, with a toasty slightly bitter finish. Its real viscous and syrupy feeling. A tasty beer but perhaps slightly sweet and syrupy for me.
deep red brown ,malt dark berry fruits little toffee,sweet rich caramel malts, little alcohol sweet caramalized suger linger

Tap at Berlin beerfest.
Pours deep brown with beige head.
Aroma is sweet caramel and grains. 
Taste is lightly roasted with caramel, light coffee and some dark fruits (cherry/prunes).
Well balanced, highly drinkable and the highlight of my tastings at the Berlin beertfets 2008.
16 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $4.29 Excellent.

Draught: Poured a dark brown color with a beige head. The aroma is chocolate, nuts, and caramel. Taste is sweet caramel malt with hints of chocolate and nuts. One of the best beers of my weekend at BBF08!

(GERMANY) Pours a dark brown / amber color with a med-tan head. This bock has a chocolate, caramel, and roasted nuts aroma. The taste is of raisins, dark malts, molasses !! The mouthfeel is smooth and lite, but well balanced, and very refreshing. I would like another...... :)

Bottled, BB 3/18/09.  Poured clear, brilliant reddish-tea with a short-ish cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up toasted caramel, nutty notes, and chocolate.. dry with a fresh herbal accent.. lovely!  The flavor had a toasty impression with sweeter bread, aged caramel, and cola.. the back-end had brighter grassy and herbal bitterness that carried through the dry finish.  The body was a bit lighter than expected and could’ve used more heft across the middle.. otherwise very well balanced with a memorable, dry finish.  I could drink a whole lot of this.
UPDATED: DEC 23, 2008 Sweet syrupy aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and hops. Very sweet syrupy flavor is roasted malts, coffee, some chocolate and hops.

Deep ruby brown hue with a thin light tan head.  Aroma is rich roasted grains, toffee - dark cherries and plums abound.  Flavor is a very nice mouthful of raisins, dark cherries, black strap molasses and dark rum.  This is a really fine dopplebock, one of the best I have had.  Finish is lingering, slightly syrupy.

500. Pours nearly black with a towering, sudsy tan head. Decent lace on the way down. Big bready and cookie-dough-ish nose. Chocolate, biscuit, and nuts there as well. Very pastry-like. Thin, watery body; very little carb. Sweet cookies, chocolate, brown bread, and biscuit and nuts all coming back around for the mid-palate. It’s so understated as to almost go right by you without making much of an impression, but it’s beautifully done and to be commended. Not sure how often I could drink this...I definitely prefer a bit more amplification in my beers, usually.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2008 Bottle thanks to Eric. Pours a ruby body with a medium beige head. The aroma is full of sweet fruits, malt, and some candy. The taste exhibits many qualities of a good bock; caramel and molasses sweetness, dark fruity flavors, a touch of alcohol warmth, a smooth easy mouthfeel, and a light bitter finish. Very good. Sweet, but not too sweet.

16oz bottle. Pours a dark dark brown with an awesome long lasting frothy beige head. Nose is dark chocolate, caramel and wheat. Some hops on this but light and just to provide balance.
